node.text:
This video is part of the Online Herbal Medicine Making Course. 
The herbalists featured in this video are "Artemisia Dawnsong," aka Juliet Blankespoor of Chestnut School of Herbal Medicine, and "News Anchor Beverly," aka Asia Suler of One Willow Apothecaries (http://www.onewillowapothecaries.com). MEDICINAL HONEYS AND SYRUPS

When the temperatures drop and the nights grow longer, my attention is inevitably drawn to the impending cold and flu season. Herbal syrups are one of my favorite medicinal preparations for respiratory infections, especially in winter. Silky and sweet, golden with summer’s nectar and sipped by the spoonful—medicinal honeys can be divinely flavorful. 
I prefer honey-based syrups over sugar or glycerin syrups for many reasons. First and foremost, I love the alchemy of honey—the synergy of flowers and bees, the sacred geometry of the hive, the fanning of wings concentrating summer’s goodness into a nourishing food that can miraculously withstand millennia. Honey also has its own medicinal virtues, imparting anti-microbial and anti-inflammatory benefits to the syrup. It helps to coat the throat, easing the spasms of dry hacking coughs and effectively taming nagging nighttime coughs. As you can imagine, honey can be quite soothing for sore throats. And, children have a special affinity for honey—they are typically a good bit more excited about taking a medicinal syrup than straight tea or tincture. 
VERY IMPORTANT SAFETY NOTE: Do not give honey to babies  under one year as there is a possibility that botulism (Clostridium  botulinum) endospores can be present. The risk is that these spores can grow into a potentially fatal botulism infection in a baby’s immature digestive system.

node.text:
Take a sneak peek into our 375-hour Online Foraging Course: Edible and Medicinal Wild Herbs, which begins in 2018! The course begins with the basic ground rules of foraging safety and ethics, and then moves on to botany and plant identification. Before you know it, you’ll have the skills and confidence to safely identify and harvest wild plants.

You’ll befriend THE most common edible and medicinal wayside plants, including dandelion, stinging nettles, violet, yarrow, burdock, rose, goldenrod, and many others. The printable manual is hundreds of pages long and filled with close-up photos for identification, medicinal uses, and loads of easy-to-follow recipes. In fact, most of our plant profiles contain more detail than you’ll find in any book on wild foods and herbs.

Registration for this online course is only open once a year. The course runs January 15th through November 1st, 2019! {The Chestnut School is dedicated to sustainability, and the plants featured are weedy, abundant plants with a global distribution. The course does not include rare and endangered plants.} #chestnutschoolforagingcourse #chestnutschoolofherbalmedicine #chestnutherbalimmersion #chestnutmedicinemakingcourse #medicinemaking #apothecary #medicinalherbs #permaculture #forager #foraging #foodasmedicine #wildherbs #wildfoods

node.text:
Imagine a medicine chest stocked with homemade herbal remedies, an apothecary lined with handcrafted tinctures, salves and tea blends. Picture a pantry brimming with botanical vinegars, oils and honeys. Sumptuous sauces, butters and salts, infused with the flavor and medicine of fresh herbs. All made with your own hands.

The Herbal Medicine Making Course gives you the know-how to create an abundant home apothecary. You’ll receive 12 videos, 38 lessons, and over 100 herbal recipes – medicinal preparations, wild foods dishes, natural body care products and culinary herbal concoctions.

The course is broken down into three easy-to-use modules: * Foundations of Medicine Making
* Bringing Healing Herbs into the Kitchen
* Topical Herbal Preparations and Body Care 
We recently upgraded this course with a whole new section on Herbal Livelihoods, which boldly traverses business topics such as insurance, marketing, legalities, websites, labeling, and an introduction to the GMPs. If you want to learn how to make high quality medicine and start an herbal products business, this program’s got you covered! The Herbal Livelihoods Guide is peppered with motivational tips and filled with ALL of my insider scoops for running an herbal business.

All skill levels are welcome!

node.text:
The Herbal Immersion Program is the most comprehensive handcrafted herbal course out there (with close to 100 videos and a gorgeous printable course manual that is 1,446 pages long). The program covers growing medicinal plants, foraging, plant identification, nutrition, therapeutics, herbal livelihoods, and medicine making.

If you want to be the kind of herbalist who has dirt under her nails, garlic mustard on her breath, and an apothecary full of homegrown medicine, then check out the Immersion. The course manual is blooming-hot with 1,446 pages, filled with bodacious botanical centerfolds and over a hundred scrumptious herbal and wild foods recipes. 
Your garden and kitchen cupboards will never be the same again!

The program features 93 videos and 152 lessons, clearly organized into 17 modules of herb-packed instruction.

In this course, you’ll delve deeply into: * Herbal Botany
* Foraging and Wild-Harvesting
* Edible Flowers
* Permaculture and Organic Gardening
* Herbal Materia Medica
* Creating Your Dream Garden
* Medicinal Plant Propagation
* Useful Garden Weeds
* Herbal Medicine Making
* Fire Ciders
* Herbal Cocktails and Mocktails
* Medicinal Mushrooms
* Herbal Body Care
* How to Make an Herbal Livelihood

and much, much more!

This course is best suited for those looking to learn how to create the herb garden of your dreams and establish a truly abundant apothecary of hand-hewn botanical medicine. All skill levels welcome.

node.text:
With billowy clusters of creamy flowers that reign over ferny leaves, meadowsweet is certainly deserving of its moniker: queen of the meadow.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
The flavor of the leaves and flowers is a fine hybrid of black tea and wintergreen, with a touch of marshmallow. Most people, including finicky children, love the tasty tea.  Meadowsweet as a tea or tincture is used as an anti-inflammatory, analgesic, and digestive aid.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Owing to meadowsweet’s anti-inflammatory, astringent, and demulcent qualities, it is used for inflammation in the gastrointestinal tract, including heartburn, peptic ulcers, and inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). It is one of my trusted remedies for heartburn, along with licorice, marshmallow, and calendula.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Meadowsweet also finds its way into formulas for arthritis. It contains methyl salicylates—anti-inflammatory and pain-relieving compounds that are found in drugs like aspirin. Did you know meadowsweet is the herb that inspired aspirin? True story! (Many folks think willow was the original inspiration, but that's a common misconception even though it also contains salicylic acid).⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Care to learn more about growing + using meadowsweet? Join us for our Online Herbal Immersion—THE most comprehensive online program in sustainable DIY herbalism in the world. Link via our bio 💚⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
(Filipenduls ulmaria).⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Photo © Juliet Blankespoor⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
*Please research any new herb and consult your health care providers for possible drug/herb contraindications and precautions before ingesting. Be sure of your identification before ingesting any plant or mushroom.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀

node.text:
The days following a flurry of summer storms are a prime time to gather Usnea from recently downed trees and branches ⛈️⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Usnea is a medicinal lichen, which is a symbiotic organism, consisting of a fungi and algae. It is fairly easy to recognize, with its thin string-like branching pattern. Usnea can be differentiated from similar lichens by pulling one of the "strings" slowly apart and looking for a thin white strand at the core.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Usnea is such an important medicinal herb to have in the medicine cabinet. It's anti-viral, anti-bacterial, anti-fungal and anti-protozoan. It's especially helpful in treating respiratory congestion, as it is drying and anti-inflammatory, in addition to its antimicrobial properties.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
It is also one of my most used remedies for urinary tract infections, along with corn silk, uva-ursi and marshmallow root. Most urinary tract infections can be successfully treated with this protocol, along with unsweetened cranberry juice.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Want to learn more about herbs for the immune system? Check out our Herbal Immune Hub. It's loaded with articles, recipes, and even a video lesson featuring Chestnut School Queen Bee, Juliet Blankespoor.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
https://chestnutherbs.com/herbs-for-immune-system-support/⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
(Usnea spp., Parmeliaceae).⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀

node.text:
Harriet Tubman was an herbalist.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
As a child, Harriet's father taught her how to identify wild plants and make medicines. She knew which foods she could eat from the forests and hedgerows. This knowledge was essential when she escaped enslavement around the age of 30.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Peoples enslaved in Africa and brought to North America (or born into slavery) carried with them rich and nuanced healing practices and materia medicas. Seeds came across the ocean, braided into hair, and so did herbal and spiritual legacies. The Black and African imprint on North American herbalism, healing, and midwifery is significant, and not generally well understood or acknowledged. Interwoven with Native American and European herbal traditions, it is foundational to our alternative healing practices today.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Want to learn more about Black North American Herbalism? Visit our three-part blog series, written by Marc N. Williams @plantsandhealers. Links in our bio 🌹⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Who are your herbal heroines?⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Marc Williams is a devoted ethnobotanist. He has studied the people, plant, mushroom, and microbe interconnection intensively while learning to employ botanicals and other life forms for food, medicine, and beauty in a regenerative manner. He has taught hundreds of classes about the marvelous world of plants, people, and their interface while working with over 60 organizations. You can connect with some of his teachings by donation via his site Botany Every Day: http://www.botanyeveryday.com/⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Photo by H.B. Lindsley.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀

node.text:
What plants and trees can you name when you look out at your landscape?
.
Knowing the green world around us increases our sense of belonging, kinship, connection, and Home. This little snippet is from Mary Plantwalker's garden @herbmountainfarm. She says:⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
"When I look out into the forest, field, garden, or roadside, I see countless allies. Green friends who have so much to share with us humans. Wherever I go in the world, I’m never without a friend, as even in a city street crack, I find a flora familiar."⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Mary guides plant walks on this farm (you can book a private tour!) and offers seasonal Appalachian Tea Ceremonies. Follow @herbmountainfarm and join their mailing list to stay tuned.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Mary also writes for our blog! Check out her articles on Medicinal Herb Gardening for Beginners, Herbal Tea Ceremonies, Growing an Herbal Tea Garden, and more via the links in our bio 🌈⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
📷 @herbmountainfarm⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀

node.text:
Blueberry medicine 💙⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Did you know blueberries tout a serious medicinal lineage?⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Blueberries are high in antioxidant bioflavonoids and are a wonderful tonic food for keeping the heart and mind healthy.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Foods high in antioxidants help reduce the stress of free radical damage on cellular DNA, and thus can reduce our risk of developing cancer. Blueberries are closely related to cranberries, and can be used similarly in the treatment of urinary tract infections.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Blueberry leaf is also medicinal, and has been used since the Middle Ages in Europe for lowering blood sugar. The leaf can be gathered, dried and prepared as a tasty tea—I find its flavor reminiscent of black tea with lemon.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Any wild species, or organically cultivated variety of blueberry, can be used medicinally.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Want to learn more about food as medicine? Join us for our Online Herbal Immersion—it's THE most comprehensive online program in sustainable herbalism. Link in bio 🌈⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
(Vaccinium spp., Ericaceae).⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀

node.text:
The work of an herbalist can take oh-so-many forms 🌹⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
My own path has been full of herbal experimentation; I’ve launched an herbal products business, seen clients as a clinical herbalist, opened a school of herbal medicine, started a medicinal plants nursery, and most recently branched out into online education, herbal writing, and serious botanical photography.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
There really is no limit to the possibilities! What’s important is that you find your happy place. Maybe this will involve working with people in a healing capacity, or perhaps you’ll feel drawn to work primarily with the plants themselves.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
There are countless ways that herbalists can creatively diversify their endeavors. For a tour of possible herbal livelihoods to help inspire you, download our 100-page Guide for Budding Herbalists. It’s yours for FREE!⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀

node.text:
Red clover is one of my favorite summertime wildflowers, and a staple in my apothecary. The soft blooms are a nutritive herb (packed with vitamins and minerals), and are traditionally used to help clear pesky skin conditions, provide relief from hot flashes and other hormonal changes during menopause, and move the lymph.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
The blossoms and upper leaves of red clover are used for medicine, but take care—the flowers mold easily, and purchased red clover is often of poor quality. If you can gather you own, make sure to dry the flowers in a warm place that gets plenty of air flow.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Want to learn more about red clover and other seasonal medicinals? You're cordially invited to join us for our Online Herbal Immersion—THE most comprehensive online program in DIY herbalism there is!⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
🌸🌸 Link in bio 🌸🌸⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀

node.text:
What's your must-have culinary herb in the garden?⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Sage here is one of my favorites—I add it to scrambled eggs, herbed goat cheese, roasted butternut squash, herbal finishing salts, pulled pork and other meat dishes, the list goes on.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
In addition to sage's illustrious culinary uses, it's also a versatile medicinal herb. This mint family garden staple has been used therapeutically for centuries with far-reaching applications, ranging from soothing sore throats, to sharpening the wits, to fending off the plague. In fact, its name heralds from the Latin salvere, "to save", referring to sage’s epic reputation as a lifesaver.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
I especially rely on sage as a steam inhalation to break up respiratory congestion. Try combining it with thyme and wild bergamot in the steam pot, along with a few drops of eucalyptus essential oil.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
We offer a wealth of sage-acious medicinal wisdom in our Online Herbal Immersion. Curious to join us? Visit: www.chestnutherbs.com/immersion⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
(Salvia officinalis, Lamiaceae).⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀

node.text:
Frida Kahlo, in her home garden at Casa Azul, 1951.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Frida is well-known for wearing flowers twined into her hair, and she made a point to fill her garden with plants native to Mexico like agave, yucca, dahlias, cacti, and bougainvillea.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
At the end of her life, she had her bed moved into a hallway so she could look out over the garden.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
